study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefit of emollient use (particularly V0034CR) in preventing flares and reducing corticosteroid use in children with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: Regular use of V0034CR emollient significantly reduced flare frequency (35.1% vs. 67.6% without emollient) and corticosteroid consumption (23.6% vs. 43.3%) compared to no emollient. Patients using emollients also had longer time to first flare, fewer flares, higher remission rates, and lower symptom scores.
population_specificity: Children aged 2 to 6 years with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of emollients in treating cutaneous xerosis in an African population and evaluate secondary outcomes like pruritus, quality of life, and tolerance.
results_summary: The emollient significantly reduced xerosis symptoms (SRRC score) by over 80% in both children and adults after 8 weeks, with notable improvements in pruritus and quality of life. The effect was stronger when combined with topical steroids or in patients with co-dermatosis.
population_specificity: Children above 3 years and adults from seven sub-Saharan African countries.
interactions: Enhanced effect when co-prescribed with topical steroids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanism of action, clinical efficacy, and safety of dupilumab for treating moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis, not emollients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about emollients; it focuses on dupilumab's potential as a treatment for atopic dermatitis.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis (not specific to emollients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review literature on the use of emollients in treating Polymorphic Eruption of Pregnancy (PEP).
results_summary: The study found that topical treatment with emollients and low-medium potency steroids is usually effective for PEP, though systemic steroids may sometimes be required. PEP is self-limiting and resolves after delivery or shortly after onset.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, particularly primigravidae and those with twin pregnancies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a Rhealba Oat Extract-based emollient in relieving chronic pruritus and improving xerosis in elderly adults.
results_summary: The emollient significantly reduced pruritus intensity and improved xerosis compared to the non-treatment phase, with over half of subjects reporting improvement and 30% experiencing complete relief. Hydration and clinical assessments also showed significant benefits.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥60 years with xerosis-associated chronic pruritus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the role of emollients in managing contact dermatitis, comparing their efficacy and application in different body regions.
results_summary: The study emphasizes that liberal use of emollients is a cornerstone therapy for contact dermatitis, alongside allergen avoidance. It reviews predisposing conditions and treatment options but does not provide specific efficacy data.
population_specificity: Patients with irritant or allergic contact dermatitis, particularly focusing on acral regions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current therapies for atopic dermatitis, including emollients, and explore potential new treatment strategies targeting the chemokine/chemokine-receptor system.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that current therapies, including emollients, alleviate symptoms but have limited efficiency and side-effects, highlighting the need for better treatments. It does not provide specific results on emollients' efficacy but discusses their role in symptom management.
population_specificity: Children and adults in developed countries affected by atopic dermatitis (15-30% of children, 2-10% of adults).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a cooling compound (CC) containing TRPM8 agonists compared to a vehicle in alleviating pruritus in patients with dry itchy skin.
results_summary: The CC lotion significantly improved pruritus more than the vehicle, with 79.2% of CC-treated patients showing improvement versus 47.1% in the vehicle group. The CC group also reported a strong, long-lasting cooling effect and improved quality of life, with no severe adverse events reported.
population_specificity: 70 patients with dry skin and pruritus intensity ≥3 on the Numerical Rating Scale (NRS).
effective_dosage: Twice daily application (specific concentration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of four emollients for treating childhood eczema and evaluate recruitment strategies for trials in primary care and pediatric populations.
results_summary: The study successfully recruited 197 participants, exceeding the target of 160, with similar numbers from self-referral and in-consultation pathways. The in-consultation pathway was more problematic due to data verification issues, and practice deprivation was associated with higher recruitment in this pathway.
population_specificity: Children with eczema, initially aged up to 3 years (later expanded to 5 years), recruited via general practitioner surgeries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide guidelines for managing atopic dermatitis, including the use of emollients as part of the treatment regimen.
results_summary: Emollients were recommended for both mild and moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis, often in combination with other treatments like topical steroids or calcineurin inhibitors. The study suggests emollients contribute to good outcomes when part of an individualized therapeutic approach.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to severe atopic dermatitis, including children and adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review global usage patterns of topical antipsoriatics, including emollients, in psoriasis patients.
results_summary: Emollients were used as monotherapy by 1-23% of psoriasis patients across different regions. Patient-reported adherence to topical remedies ranged from 51% to 90%, while satisfaction with symptom control ranged from 12% to 52%.
population_specificity: Psoriasis patients from North/South America, North/Central/South Europe, Asia, Middle East, and Australia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing psychogenic pruritus as part of general measures to prevent skin dryness and alleviate symptoms.
results_summary: The study suggests that frequent application of emollients is a general measure for managing psychogenic pruritus, alongside avoiding irritating factors and preventing skin dryness. However, the primary focus of the abstract is on psychopharmacotherapy and psychotherapy, with limited detail on emollient-specific outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with psychogenic pruritus (functional itch disorder).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing chronic pruritus in the elderly, considering their multifactorial causes and the need for holistic treatment approaches.
results_summary: The study highlights that emollients are a key component of topical therapies for symptomatic relief of chronic itch in the elderly, often used alongside other treatments for underlying conditions. It emphasizes the challenge of managing itch in this population due to multifactorial causes and polypharmacy risks.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals over 65 years old with chronic pruritus lasting more than 6 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing atopic dermatitis (AD) and their potential for preventing AD development when applied early.
results_summary: The study found that emollients are effective for managing dry skin in AD and suggested that early application from birth may prevent AD development.
population_specificity: Children, particularly those at risk for or diagnosed with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of combining glycolic acid peels with a modified Kligman formula (MKF) for treating facial postinflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH) in Indian patients, with emollients used to manage side effects.
results_summary: The study found that combining glycolic acid peels with MKF was more effective than MKF alone in reducing PIH, with side effects managed by liberal emollient application. No dropouts occurred due to side effects.
population_specificity: Indian patients with Fitzpatrick skin Types III-V and facial PIH.
effective_dosage: Not specified for emollients (used as needed for side effects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of Dr. Michaels® skin-care products, including emollients, for managing lamellar ichthyosis.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in skin condition, including reduced scaling, fissuring, erythema, and pruritus, with normalization of skin color and partial nail resolution after 12-15 weeks. No adverse reactions were observed.
population_specificity: 10 patients (3 female/7 male) aged 38-54 with lamellar ichthyosis.
effective_dosage: Topical treatments (cleansing gel, activator formula, ointment) and oral herbal supplements (PSC 200, PSC 400, PSC 900); exact frequency not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of emollients in maintaining skin barrier function to prevent allergen and microbial penetration in atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The study found that emollients help maintain normal skin barrier function, preventing allergens and microbes from penetrating the skin, which is crucial for managing atopic dermatitis and preventing systemic allergen sensitization.
population_specificity: Individuals with atopic dermatitis, particularly those at risk of food allergy due to impaired skin barrier function.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically discuss skin care practices, including the use of emollients, in the context of professional nursing, focusing on safety, efficacy, and the importance of accurate skin assessment.
results_summary: The study highlights that emollients can hydrate, moisturize, protect, and restore skin properties but may also cause unwanted side effects like hyper-hydration, barrier dysfunction, and increased susceptibility to irritants. Proper skin assessment and product selection are crucial to avoid harmful responses.
population_specificity: General skin care practices in nursing and healthcare, including formal and informal caregivers.

study_goal: To determine the feasibility of a randomized controlled trial of 'leave on' emollients for children with eczema, including recruitment, retention, and data collection.
results_summary: The study found it feasible to recruit and randomize young children with eczema to emollients, with good data collection and observer blinding. However, only 10% of parents reported daily use of the allocated emollient, and non-study emollient use was common.
population_specificity: Children with eczema aged 1 month to <5 years in the UK.
effective_dosage: Not specified (Aveeno lotion, Diprobase cream, Doublebase gel, Hydromol ointment used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current and emerging topical therapies, including emollients, for treating atopic dermatitis (AD), focusing on safety, efficacy, and limitations.
results_summary: Emollients are part of the current treatment for AD, but the abstract highlights their limitations in providing rapid relief from pruritus compared to other therapies like TCSs and TCIs. Emerging PDE4 inhibitors are noted as potential alternatives for more targeted anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Patients with mild-to-moderate atopic dermatitis (children and adults).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in treating cutaneous barrier dysfunction as part of the evidence-based strategies for managing atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: The study found that topical application of emollients is a primary measure for treating cutaneous barrier dysfunction in AD, alongside other treatments like corticosteroids and tacrolimus ointment. The guidelines recommend emollients as part of a comprehensive approach to optimize patient outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD) in Japan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a new emollient balm on clinical parameters, skin barrier function, and skin microflora balance in children with mild atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The emollient group showed significant improvements in SCORAD, pruritus, and xerosis, along with reduced transepidermal water loss and involucrin expression. The emollient also protected against S. aureus proliferation and preserved microflora biodiversity.
population_specificity: Children aged 1-4 years with mild atopic dermatitis.
effective_dosage: Twice daily application of the emollient balm.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to outline the use, dosage, safety, and efficacy of narrowband UVB (NB-UVB) and targeted phototherapy, including adjunctive treatments like emollients, for psoriasis.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that NB-UVB is commonly used with adjunctive topical treatments such as emollients, but specific effects or outcomes related to emollients alone are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriasis affecting >10% of body surface area who have not responded to topical treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the moisturizing efficacy and acceptability of two emollients, Doublebase Dayleve gel (DELP) and Diprobase cream (DIPC), in female eczema patients with dry skin.
results_summary: DELP showed significantly higher moisturizing efficacy than DIPC, with AUC values three times greater after 24 hours and five times greater after 5 days of use. Subjects also preferred DELP, with 75% favoring it over DIPC, and higher rates of willingness to use it again.
population_specificity: Female eczema subjects with dry skin.
study_duration: Part 1: 24 hours (single application); Part 2: 5 days (twice daily applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether topical emollients (ointments, creams, or oils) could reduce invasive infection, mortality, and other morbidity in preterm infants by improving skin barrier function.
results_summary: The study found no significant evidence that emollient therapy prevents invasive infection or death in preterm infants across high-, middle-, or low-income settings. Some evidence suggested vegetable oils may improve neonatal growth, but results were heterogeneous and potentially biased due to lack of blinding.
population_specificity: Preterm infants, including very preterm infants in healthcare facilities across high-, middle-, and low-income countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the lack of consensus on emollient use in term newborns and the need for further research to guide clinical practice.
results_summary: The abstract notes that emollients are frontline treatment for atopic dermatitis (AD) but emphasizes the limited information available on their use in term newborns, stressing the need for more research.
population_specificity: Term newborns (compared to preterm infants and adults).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the clinical and cost-effectiveness of adding bath emollients to standard eczema care in children compared to standard care alone.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results in the abstract, but it aimed to measure long-term eczema severity, exacerbations, quality of life, and cost-effectiveness over 16 weeks and 1 year.
population_specificity: Children aged 12 months to 12 years with eczema (excluding inactive or very mild cases).
study_duration: 16 weeks for primary outcome, 1 year for secondary outcomes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of a botanical anti-inflammatory acne regimen containing emollients against a traditional benzoyl peroxide regimen in improving acne lesions and skin appearance.
results_summary: The botanical regimen showed superior early improvements in lesion characteristics (erythema, height, inflammation, pus) at weeks 2 and 4, with sustained reductions in closed comedones and inflammatory lesions by week 12 compared to the benzoyl peroxide regimen.
population_specificity: 80 male and female subjects aged 12+ years with mild to moderate acne (≥10 inflammatory and ≥10 non-inflammatory lesions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the treatment options, including emollients, for Erythrokeratodermia variabilis et progressiva (EKVP).
results_summary: The study found that emollients, along with topical keratolytics, resulted in some improvement in hyperkeratosis for EKVP patients. Low-dose systemic retinoids were also noted as potentially beneficial.
population_specificity: Individuals with Erythrokeratodermia variabilis et progressiva (EKVP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the clinical effectiveness of oral and topical antibiotics, in addition to standard treatment with emollients and topical corticosteroids, in children with clinically infected eczema.
results_summary: The study found that oral and topical antibiotics had no effect or a harmful effect on subjective eczema severity in children with clinically infected eczema, with no meaningful beneficial effect observed. Outcomes were consistent across multiple measures, showing worse or no difference in severity compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Children aged 3 months to <8 years with a diagnosis of eczema and clinical suspicion of infection.
effective_dosage: Not specified for emollients (standard treatment). Antibiotics: oral flucloxacillin and topical fusidic acid for 1 week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing symptomatic palmoplantar keratoderma in patients with tylosis.
results_summary: The study found that regular application of emollients is part of the symptomatic management of palmoplantar keratoderma, alongside other interventions like specialist footwear and early treatment of fissures and infections.
population_specificity: Patients with tylosis (hyperkeratosis palmaris et plantaris) and associated high risk of oesophageal cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether heparinoid moisturizer could improve skin water content and reduce dryness and desquamation in patients undergoing whole-breast radiotherapy after lumpectomy.
results_summary: The study found that heparinoid moisturizer significantly increased skin water content and reduced dryness and desquamation compared to no moisturizer, with a notable improvement observed within 2 weeks of application.
population_specificity: Patients receiving whole-breast radiotherapy after lumpectomy (30 in the moisturizer group, 32 in the control group).
effective_dosage: Application from 2 weeks post-radiotherapy until 3 months after completion (frequency not specified).
study_duration: 2 weeks of application (measured at 4 weeks post-radiotherapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in restoring epidermal barrier function for the prevention and treatment of atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The study found that emollients are effective in restoring epidermal barrier function and are a primary focus for prevention and treatment of atopic dermatitis, though topical corticosteroids remain first-line for acute flares.
population_specificity: Individuals with atopic dermatitis, including children and adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the clinical features, genetic basis, and therapeutic options (including emollients) for Ichthyosis with confetti (IWC).
results_summary: The study found that emollients, along with keratolytics, provide symptomatic and temporary relief for IWC, but no specific or satisfactory therapy is currently available. Systemic treatments like retinoids improve symptoms in most patients.
population_specificity: Patients with Ichthyosis with confetti (IWC), a rare genodermatosis with a prevalence <1/1,000,000.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether silk therapeutic garments combined with standard eczema care (including emollients) are more effective than standard care alone in managing moderate to severe eczema in children.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding emollients, as the study focuses on comparing silk therapeutic garments plus standard care versus standard care alone. Full results will be published later.
population_specificity: Children aged 1 to 15 years with moderate to severe eczema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effectiveness of emollients, both as a group and individually, in treating atopic dermatitis (AD) and related conditions.
results_summary: The study found that moisturizers generally have beneficial effects on clinical symptoms, transepidermal water loss (TEWL), and stratum corneum hydration, with urea and glycerin showing more documented clinical effects compared to other ingredients. However, direct comparisons between individual moisturizers were scarce, and glycerin studies often had a higher risk of bias.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis, irritant hand dermatitis, and/or ichthyosis vulgaris.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in the management of hand eczema, alongside other treatments.
results_summary: Emollients were identified as a mainstay in managing hand eczema, particularly for patient education and preventive measures, but their efficacy compared to other treatments like topical corticosteroids or systemic therapies was not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with hand eczema, including severe forms impacting quality of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of recruiting and retaining children with eczema for a randomized trial comparing four emollients and to collect preliminary data on their acceptability and effectiveness.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so definitive results are not yet available, but it will provide data on recruitment feasibility and preliminary effectiveness of four emollients (Aveeno® lotion, Diprobase® cream, Doublebase® gel, and Hydromol® ointment) in managing eczema.
population_specificity: Children aged 1 month to less than 5 years with eczema, not allergic to study emollients or their constituents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of wet wrap therapy using emollients compared to topical corticosteroids for treating severe and refractory atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: Wet wrap therapy with topical corticosteroids was more effective than emollients alone for short-term treatment, but had a higher risk of infections. Emollients showed no long-term adverse effects, but mechanisms of action were poorly investigated.
population_specificity: Patients with severe and refractory atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential effects and risks of applying fresh human milk locally on eczema spots in children with atopic eczema, compared to emollient treatment alone.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of fresh human milk on eczema spots compared to emollient alone, with mixed results in relative changes in eczema area. No secondary infections due to milk application were detected.
population_specificity: Children with atopic eczema (mean age 18.5 months) who had a mother breastfeeding them or a sibling.
effective_dosage: Emollient applied three times a day (frequency specified; exact amount not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the symptomatic treatment options, including emollients, for managing hyperkeratosis in Olmsted syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that current treatments, including emollients, offer only temporary and partial relief for hyperkeratosis in Olmsted syndrome, with no specific or satisfactory therapy available.
population_specificity: Patients with Olmsted syndrome, a rare genodermatosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing atopic dermatitis (AD) in children, particularly in addressing skin barrier dysfunction and hydration.
results_summary: The study highlights that emollients are essential for skin hydration and barrier repair in children with AD, supporting their use as a foundational treatment. It also mentions additional therapies like bleach baths and wet wrap therapy for more severe cases.
population_specificity: Children with atopic dermatitis, particularly in Asia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of emollients as a first-line treatment for itch, particularly in inflammatory skin diseases.
results_summary: The abstract highlights emollients as a first-line topical therapy for itch, though it does not provide specific efficacy data for emollients alone. It emphasizes that treatment effectiveness varies based on the underlying cause of itch.
population_specificity: Patients with itch from inflammatory skin diseases, systemic diseases, neuropathic conditions, or psychogenic disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a skin barrier emulsion cream versus a moisturizing lotion in improving the epidermal barrier in individuals with atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The study was a pilot with a small sample size, suggesting preliminary data but no definitive comparative results between the two emollient options for atopic dermatitis treatment.
population_specificity: Subjects with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of a urea, arginine, and carnosine cream (UC) versus a glycerin-based emollient cream (SEC) in improving severe foot skin xerosis in type 2 diabetic patients over 8 months.
results_summary: UC significantly improved skin hydration and reduced xerosis scores compared to SEC, with noticeable benefits as early as 4 weeks. Objective measurements confirmed better skin hydration and reduced desquamation in the UC group by the end of the study.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic patients with severe foot xerosis (N=50).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how emollient treatment affects microbial communities on affected and unaffected skin in patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: Emollient treatment improved clinical symptoms in 72% of patients, increased microbial diversity, reduced Staphylococcus abundance, and showed a potential role for Stenotrophomonas species in restoring the skin microbiome.
population_specificity: 49 patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing symptoms of Empty Nose Syndrome (ENS), particularly nasal dryness and crusting.
results_summary: The abstract mentions emollients as part of medical therapies for ENS, but no specific outcomes or efficacy data are provided regarding their use.
population_specificity: Patients with Empty Nose Syndrome (ENS) following turbinate surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the preventive efficacy of daily emollient use in newborns at high risk of atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: The study found that daily use of emollients in high-risk newborns reduced the cumulative incidence of AD by 32% to 50%. Other strategies like allergen avoidance showed questionable efficacy, while supplementation approaches required further investigation.
population_specificity: Newborns at high risk of atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of prolonged-release oxycodone/naloxone (PR OXN) compared to prolonged-release oxycodone (PR OXY) for pain relief and opioid-induced constipation (OIC) in patients with severe chronic pain and laxative-refractory OIC.
results_summary: PR OXN significantly reduced pain and OIC, with a 95% responder rate, improved quality of life, and reduced laxative use compared to PR OXY. Adverse events were opioid-related but well-tolerated.
population_specificity: Patients with severe chronic pain and laxative-refractory OIC (mean age 59.8 years, 67.6% female, 91.2% non-malignant pain).
effective_dosage: Median daily dose of 20 mg PR OXN.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential causes and treatments of uremic pruritus (UP), including the role of emollients as a common treatment.
results_summary: The abstract mentions emollients as one of the common treatments for UP, but does not provide specific efficacy data or comparative results for emollients alone.
population_specificity: Patients with uremic pruritus, including those undergoing dialysis and those with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily full-body emollient therapy from birth could reduce the incidence of atopic dermatitis in high-risk neonates.
results_summary: The study found a 50% relative risk reduction in atopic dermatitis incidence at 6 months with daily emollient use, with no reported adverse events or differences between groups. Families found the intervention acceptable, and the approach was deemed feasible, safe, and effective.
population_specificity: High-risk neonates in the United States and United Kingdom.
effective_dosage: Full-body application at least once per day.
study_duration: From birth until 6 months of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of emollients in managing atopic dermatitis, focusing on their importance in restoring the impaired cutaneous barrier and their integration into treatment strategies.
results_summary: The study found that emollients, along with avoidance of irritants, are crucial for managing atopic dermatitis due to their role in improving the skin barrier. Topical anti-inflammatory treatments were highlighted as central, with emollients serving as a supportive measure.
population_specificity: Children and adults with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if early introduction of frequent oil baths and facial fat cream could reduce xerosis and possibly atopic eczema in infants with dry skin.
results_summary: The intervention group (oil baths and facial fat cream) had significantly more infants with normal skin (75%) at six months compared to the observation group (37.5%), and fewer cases of probable atopic eczema (4.0% vs. 19.0%). No adverse reactions were reported.
population_specificity: Six-week-old infants with xerosis but not atopic eczema.
effective_dosage: Oil bath (0.5 dl) and facial fat cream, performed 2-4 up to 5-7 times/week.
study_duration: From six weeks to six months of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing paediatric vulvar skin conditions, emphasizing general measures like avoidance of irritants and regular emollient use.
results_summary: The study found that regular use of emollients, along with general measures like soap substitution, is helpful for all patients with paediatric vulvar skin conditions, though specific therapy depends on the underlying diagnosis.
population_specificity: Children with vulvar skin conditions, including eczema, psoriasis, lichen sclerosus, and napkin dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of emollients as part of a treatment regimen for eosinophilic folliculitis in a post-transplant patient.
results_summary: Emollients, combined with a topical corticosteroid and oral doxepin, achieved near-resolution of lesions within eight weeks, with complete clearance by 12 weeks when transitioning to topical tacrolimus.
population_specificity: A 56-year-old HIV-negative male with acute lymphoblastic leukemia who underwent haploidentical allogeneic stem cell transplantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the tolerability and efficacy of citric acid-coated textiles on improving skin barrier function and reducing symptoms in patients with atopic eczema or atopic diathesis.
results_summary: The study found that citric acid-coated textiles were well tolerated and improved eczema symptoms, skin barrier function, and hydration while reducing skin surface pH, potentially lowering pathogenic microbial colonization.
population_specificity: Twenty patients with atopic eczema or atopic diathesis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (textiles worn for 12 hours daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of a novel PEA/AEA emollient with a traditional emollient in improving skin barrier function and hydration in patients with asteatotic eczema.
results_summary: The PEA/AEA emollient showed superior improvements in skin surface capacitance and significantly increased the 5 Hz current perception threshold to normal levels within 7 days, correlating positively with hydration and negatively with transepidermal water loss. Both emollients improved some aspects, but the PEA/AEA group demonstrated better overall skin function enhancement.
population_specificity: 60 patients with mild to moderate asteatotic eczema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of topical emollients in managing hypertrophic scars in burn survivors through a systematic review of RCTs.
results_summary: The study found favorable conclusions for topical emollients in treating hypertrophic scars, though the sample size was limited (58 patients across 2 articles). The results were positive but lacked detailed statistical analysis or comparison to other treatments.
population_specificity: Burn survivors with hypertrophic scars in the non-acute setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the latest trends in the treatment of atopic dermatitis, emphasizing the role of emollients as a basic treatment.
results_summary: The study highlights that emollients are essential for restoring skin barrier function in atopic dermatitis patients, regardless of disease severity, and notes their inclusion as a foundational treatment alongside anti-inflammatory therapies.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis, including children and adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide recommendations for the use of emollients, thermal water, and skin care products in psoriasis management.
results_summary: The study found that emollients, either alone or as adjunctive therapy, can restore and protect skin barrier function, increase remission times between flare-ups, and enhance pharmaceutical therapy effects.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriasis, regardless of disease severity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of various treatments, including emollients, for pruritus in burn wound patients.
results_summary: The study found that emollients are among the treatments used for pruritus relief in burn patients, but oral antihistamines are more commonly used despite inconsistent efficacy. Few studies on emollients were methodologically robust.
population_specificity: Patients with burn wounds experiencing pruritus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to outline strategies for managing atopic dermatitis (AD), including the role of emollients in skin cleansing and therapy.
results_summary: The study found that emollients and moisturizers are primary topical therapies for AD but are poorly tolerated on inflamed skin, requiring additional treatments like corticosteroids or calcineurin inhibitors. Proactive therapy, involving patient control and avoidance of irritants, was highlighted as an effective approach.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in the treatment of atopic dermatitis (AD) in young children, alongside topical anti-inflammatory medicines, and to identify optimal outcome domains for AD clinical trials.
results_summary: Emollients, combined with topical anti-inflammatory medicines, are a mainstay therapy for AD in children, but parental education on application and long-term effects is needed. The study highlights the necessity for better outcome measures in AD clinical trials to improve disease control.
population_specificity: Very young children with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a 3-month maintenance treatment regimen with a sterile, preservative-free emollient cream containing oat plantlets in children with moderate atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in AD severity, evidenced by decreases in SCORAD and PO-SCORAD indexes, fewer flare-ups, and reduced topical corticosteroid use. Tolerance was excellent, with no adverse effects reported.
population_specificity: Children aged 6 months to 6 years with moderate AD (SCORAD index ≤ 20).
effective_dosage: Twice daily application of the emollient cream.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of emollient therapy in reducing neonatal mortality and infection rates, as well as improving growth outcomes in preterm neonates in low and middle-income countries.
results_summary: Emollient therapy significantly reduced neonatal mortality by 27% and hospital-acquired infections by 50%, while also improving weight gain. The effects on length and head circumference were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Preterm neonates in low and middle-income countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the stand-alone efficacy of an emollient formulation in improving clinical symptoms, skin barrier function, and reducing pathogenic bacterial colonization during acute atopic dermatitis flares.
results_summary: The emollient significantly reduced clinical severity, itch intensity, erythema, and TEWL, while also decreasing S. aureus colonization and improving skin hydration. No significant differences were found between the emollient and hydrocortisone arms in terms of outcomes.
population_specificity: 20 AD volunteers aged 12-65 years with symmetric, mild to moderately severe inflammatory lesions on the forearms/arms.
effective_dosage: Not specified (applied for 1 week, followed by a different emollient for 3 weeks).
study_duration: 4 weeks (1 week initial treatment, 3 weeks follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and systematic reviews of AD treatments, including emollients, to evaluate their effectiveness.
results_summary: The study found that petrolatum, an emollient, was as effective as creams containing ceramides or glycyrrhetinic acid in treating AD. Other therapeutic approaches, such as balneotherapy and nutritional interventions, were also supported by RCTs.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the historical and current use of topical analgesics, including emollients, for pain management and their potential benefits in preventing chronic pain states.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that topical analgesics, including emollients, may offer fewer systemic side effects and could be part of a multimodal approach to treat challenging pain conditions like burns and pressure ulcers. It also suggests potential benefits in preventing peripheral and central sensitization, which may reduce the transition to chronic pain.
population_specificity: Patients with pain conditions such as burns, wound debridement, pressure ulcers, and those at risk for chronic pain states like complex regional pain syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of emollients in treating atopic dermatitis (AD) and their potential alongside other established and emerging therapies.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that emollients remain a well-established treatment option for AD, focusing on reducing transepidermal water loss and improving skin barrier function, alongside other therapies like corticosteroids and topical calcineurin inhibitors.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether atopic dermatitis affects the risk of contact sensitization and allergic contact dermatitis, particularly in relation to emollient use.
results_summary: The study found that emollient use in atopic dermatitis patients increases sensitization to fragrances and other ingredients, but the immune response in atopic dermatitis may lower the risk of contact sensitization compared to healthy controls. Multiple factors influence this association.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to non-invasively determine the mechanisms of action of various moisturizing molecules, including emollients, on stratum corneum hydration and barrier function.
results_summary: The study found that ethylhexyl palmitate and caprylic/capric acid triglyceride exhibited emollient properties, aligning with existing literature. The methods used effectively characterized the hydration and barrier effects of these molecules.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or ex vivo study on stratum corneum samples).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and tolerability of long-term emollient therapy for treating moderate to severe xerosis in young children with atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The emollient significantly improved xerosis scores, skin hydration, and overall AD symptoms compared to the vehicle, with 66.1% of patients responding to treatment. Relapse occurred after stopping treatment, but symptoms improved again upon restarting emollient therapy.
population_specificity: Children aged 2-6 years with atopic dermatitis-associated xerosis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (emollient combining glycerol and paraffin, applied for 28 days initially).
study_duration: 28-day double-blind period, with extended open-label treatment up to 84 days for non-responders or relapsed patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing eczematous (stasis) dermatitis as part of skin care for edema-related conditions.
results_summary: The study found that emollients, along with topical steroid creams, are effective in managing eczematous (stasis) dermatitis, which is crucial for preventing skin breakdown and venous ulcers in patients with chronic edema.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic edema, particularly those with venous insufficiency or eczematous (stasis) dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety of bis-diglyceryl polyacyladipate-2 and bis-diglyceryl polyacyladipate-1 as emollients in cosmetic formulations.
results_summary: The study found that these ingredients are safe for use in cosmetics at current concentrations and usage practices, functioning effectively as skin-conditioning agents. The Panel based its conclusion on a review of available animal and clinical data.
population_specificity: General cosmetic use (not specified beyond animal and clinical data review).
effective_dosage: Not specified (current practices of use and concentration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of emollients in controlling epidermal nerve density and itch sensitization, particularly in atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that emollients can partly control epidermal nerve density, which is linked to itch sensitization, but highlights the need for new antipruritic treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis and chronic itch conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients as a first-line treatment for uremic pruritus in patients with chronic kidney disease.
results_summary: The study suggests emollients as part of a stepwise approach for managing chronic kidney disease-associated pruritus, recommending them as a first-line treatment alongside gabapentin or phototherapy.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced or end-stage renal disease undergoing hemodialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of emollients in improving clinical and biophysical parameters in patients with atopic dermatitis (AD) and their role in barrier repair therapy.
results_summary: The study found that emollients improve the barrier function of the stratum corneum by providing water and lipids, reducing inflammation, and restoring epidermal function. Some evidence supported their efficacy in improving AD symptoms, though study methods were often flawed and sample sizes small.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD), particularly school-aged children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence on the therapeutic benefits, safety, and tolerability of treatments, including emollients, for congenital ichthyoses (excluding ichthyosis vulgaris).
results_summary: Topical treatments, including emollients, showed therapeutic benefit and a good safety profile. However, the small sample sizes and lack of methodological rigor limit the strength of these conclusions.
population_specificity: Patients with inherited ichthyoses (syndromic or nonsyndromic, excluding ichthyosis vulgaris).
effective_dosage: Not specified for emollients (other treatments mentioned: 5% urea, 20% propylene glycol, 5% lactic acid, calcipotriol ointment, liarozole 5% cream).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of emollients in the treatment of psoriasis, particularly their historical use for skin hydration and shedding.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that emollients were used earlier for hydrating the skin or shedding off the skin in psoriasis treatment, but later treatments shifted focus to addressing underlying T-cell proliferation. No specific efficacy data for emollients is provided.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriasis (no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects and safety of oral H1 antihistamines as monotherapy in children and adults with eczema, excluding studies with concomitant therapies other than emollients or moisturizers.
results_summary: No randomized controlled trials met the inclusion criteria, so no high-level evidence supports or refutes the efficacy or safety of oral H1 antihistamines as monotherapy for eczema. The study highlights the need for well-designed trials excluding concomitant medications.
population_specificity: Children and adults with eczema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review various treatment strategies for psoriasis, including emollients, and compare their effectiveness and novel approaches.
results_summary: The abstract mentions emollients as a topical treatment option for milder forms of psoriasis but does not provide specific efficacy data. It highlights the range of treatments available, from conventional to novel approaches.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriasis (general, no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current understanding of atopic dermatitis (AD) pathogenesis and discuss the potential of new biologic therapies, including emollients, for treating AD.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that existing treatments like emollients and immunosuppressants have transient efficacy and some toxicity, while new biologic agents targeting specific pathways show promise for safer and more effective long-term AD management.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD), particularly those with moderate to severe cases.

study_goal: To compare the effectiveness of topical vitamin E versus an emollient in reducing the risk of vulvar lichen sclerosus (VLS) relapse over a 52-week maintenance treatment.
results_summary: The study found that both emollients and topical vitamin E showed similar efficacy in maintaining VLS remission, with cumulative crude relapse rates of 22.7% and 27.8%, respectively, and median times to relapse of 18.7 weeks and 20 weeks.
population_specificity: 156 patients with vulvar lichen sclerosus (VLS), with 80 entering the maintenance phase.
effective_dosage: Once daily application (specific emollient product not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety of isoparaffins as cosmetic ingredients, particularly their use as emollients.
results_summary: The CIR Expert Panel concluded that isoparaffins are safe for use in cosmetics at concentrations ranging from 0.0001% to 90%, based on animal and clinical data. No significant adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: General cosmetic use (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of AR-GG27® (sorbityl furfural palmitate) cream in treating childhood mild or moderate atopic dermatitis (AD) associated with pityriasis alba (PA).
results_summary: AR-GG27® showed statistically significant improvements in Investigator Global Assessment (IGA) scores and reduced itching compared to placebo after 15 and 30 days of treatment. The treatment was well-tolerated and demonstrated high compliance.
population_specificity: Children aged two months to 15 years with mild to moderate AD associated with PA and xerosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a 3-month, twice-daily emollient treatment on the quality of life (QoL) of parents with children suffering from mild to moderate atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in clinical condition (SCORAD dropped from 28 to 12) and parent-reported QoL (global QoL scores dropped from 4.4 to 2.1), with 85% of parents noting QoL improvement and 80% favorable opinions on safety.
population_specificity: Children with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis (SCORAD ≤ 30) and their parents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine effective medical devices and treatments, including emollients, for preventing pressure sores in high-risk patients.
results_summary: The study found that nursing care involving skin hydration with emollients, along with other preventive measures, remains valid for pressure sore prevention (level C evidence).
population_specificity: Patients with high risk of pressure sores in care or medical-social units.

study_goal: The researchers reviewed current and emerging therapies, including emollients, for chronic cutaneous GVHD in HPCT patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on emollients, focusing instead on broader therapies like electrocorporeal photopheresis and systemic agents.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic cutaneous GVHD after haemopoietic progenitor cell transplant (HPCT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing atopic dermatitis symptoms and preventing flare-ups.
results_summary: The study found that regular, liberal use of emollients is recommended for managing atopic dermatitis, helping to relieve symptoms and prolong time between flare-ups. It supports emollients as a foundational treatment alongside pharmacologic options like topical corticosteroids.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (approximately 17.8 million persons in the U.S.).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of Atrapro (RD047-26) antipruritic hydrogel in adults with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis and associated pruritus.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in all three efficacy endpoints (IGA, IPA, PIA), with 88% of participants showing reduced pruritus severity by day 14. Most participants experienced relief from itching by day 3, and the only adverse event was mild skin dryness, resolved with increased emollient use.
population_specificity: 17 adults with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis and associated pruritus.
effective_dosage: Applied 3 times daily to affected areas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing pruritus and skin barrier dysfunction in hemodialysis patients, alongside nalfurafine hydrochloride.
results_summary: The study highlighted that basic skin care with emollients is essential for stopping the itch-scratch cycle and improving skin barrier dysfunction in uremic pruritus, though the primary focus was on nalfurafine hydrochloride.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients with resistant pruritus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in the treatment and prevention of atopic dermatitis (AD) in children, alongside other integrative medicine approaches.
results_summary: Emollients are traditionally used in Western medicine for AD, but the abstract does not provide specific efficacy results for emollients alone. The focus shifts to probiotics, prebiotics, synbiotics, Chinese herbal medicine, and vitamins, with varying efficacy noted.
population_specificity: Pediatric population with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify and compare the physiochemical properties of topical emollients, focusing on pH and hydrophilic content, to assess their potential for maintaining skin barrier function and hydration.
results_summary: The study found that emollients vary widely in pH (3.7–8.2) and hydrophilic index (HI), with lotions generally having higher HI (more aqueous) and ointments lower HI (more lipid-rich). Most products fell within the physiologic skin pH range (4–6), suggesting suitability for conditions like atopic dermatitis.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on product properties, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on the etiology and treatment of post-burn pruritus, including the role of emollients.
results_summary: The abstract mentions emollients as part of current standard therapies for post-burn pruritus but highlights their limited efficacy, with antihistamines being effective in only 20% of patients. No specific results on emollients' effectiveness are detailed.
population_specificity: Burn patients experiencing post-burn pruritus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the routine clinical use of imiquimod 5% cream for actinic keratosis, including patient profiles, tolerability, and satisfaction, but did not specifically focus on emollients.
results_summary: The study noted that post-imiquimod therapy included the use of numerous emollients, but no specific results regarding their efficacy or safety were provided.
population_specificity: 463 patients with actinic keratosis, predominantly male, aged 74 years, with multiple pre-treated lesions at the face.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and management of adverse events, including skin disorders, in hepatitis C treatment regimens involving telaprevir, with a focus on the role of emollients in managing mild to moderate rashes.
results_summary: The study found that emollients, along with topical corticosteroids, were effective in managing mild to moderate rashes (90% of cases) without requiring discontinuation of telaprevir. Severe rashes were rare (5%) but led to treatment discontinuation in some cases.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing hepatitis C virus treatment with telaprevir-based regimens.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the efficacy and safety of oral atorvastatin for plaque-type psoriasis, while patients continued using emollients as part of their topical therapy.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in psoriasis improvement between the atorvastatin and placebo groups, both of which showed significant lesion improvement. Emollients were part of the continued topical therapy but their specific effects were not isolated or analyzed separately.
population_specificity: 42 patients aged 16-60 years with plaque-type psoriasis involving >10% body surface area.
effective_dosage: Not specified for emollients (atorvastatin dosage was 40 mg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish consensus recommendations on the use of emollients and other therapies for treating psoriasis in pregnant and lactating women.
results_summary: Emollients were identified as a first-line therapy for limited psoriasis in pregnant and lactating women, demonstrating safety and efficacy when used as part of a broader treatment strategy. The study emphasized their role alongside low- to moderate-potency topical steroids for managing symptoms.
population_specificity: Pregnant and lactating women with psoriasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the role of emollients in managing atopic dermatitis, including their use in conventional therapy.
results_summary: The study highlights that emollients are part of conventional therapy for atopic dermatitis, used for skin hydration alongside other treatments like topical corticosteroids and immunomodulators. No specific efficacy data on emollients alone are provided, but their inclusion in standard care suggests a supportive role.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (infantile, childhood, and adulthood stages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of topical 10% Urea ISDIN® plus dexpanthenol lotion in treating skin dryness and pruritus in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in skin dryness (82% reduction) and pruritus (94% reduction) after four weeks of treatment, with excellent/good tolerability in 14 out of 15 patients. One patient reported mild burning sensation.
population_specificity: 15 hemodialysis patients (3 men, 12 women, mean age 66 years) with skin xerosis and uraemic pruritus.
effective_dosage: Topical 10% Urea ISDIN® plus dexpanthenol lotion applied twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential anti-inflammatory and therapeutic effects of olive-derived emollients, particularly their role in mitigating chronic inflammatory diseases.
results_summary: The study suggests that olive-derived emollients, rich in omega-3 fatty acids, may inhibit chronic inflammatory processes linked to diseases like coronary artery disease, rheumatoid arthritis, hypertension, and cancer. The Mediterranean diet's association with reduced degenerative diseases was highlighted.
population_specificity: General population, particularly those with chronic inflammatory diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing dermatological adverse events (AEs) associated with telaprevir-based triple therapy for HCV infection.
results_summary: Emollients were found effective in treating mild to moderate rash (Grade 1 or 2) without requiring discontinuation of telaprevir, with symptoms commonly resolving upon discontinuation in severe cases. Severe cutaneous adverse reactions (SCAR) were rare but required immediate cessation of all medication.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing HCV treatment with peginterferon/ribavirin and telaprevir.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize key findings from systematic reviews on atopic eczema, including the effectiveness of emollients and other treatments.
results_summary: The evidence base for bath emollients, occlusive treatments, and woven silk clothing in treating eczema was found to be poor, with no clear demonstration of efficacy. The review highlighted methodological shortcomings and heterogeneity in the included studies.
population_specificity: Individuals with atopic eczema, including infants and urban vs. rural populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of emollients as an intervention for eczema in adults and children.
results_summary: The study found that emollients were among the interventions reviewed for eczema management, suggesting they are effective in treating established eczema, though specific efficacy details are not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults and children with established eczema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of lipid-based emollients in managing irritant contact dermatitis caused by transdermal rivastigmine patches.
results_summary: The study found that lipid-based emollients can alleviate irritant dermatitis from transdermal rivastigmine, allowing patients to continue treatment. Simple changes like patch rotation and avoiding harsh soaps further reduced dermatitis risk.
population_specificity: Patients using transdermal rivastigmine patches for Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term effectiveness and appeal of a non-steroidal medicated device foam (emollient) versus pimecrolimus cream 1% in treating atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: The medical device foam showed higher efficacy (82% of lesions "clear" or "almost clear") compared to pimecrolimus (71%), with no associated adverse effects reported for either treatment. Both treatments were effective in mild-to-moderate AD across a wide age group.
population_specificity: Subjects with active atopic dermatitis (AD) across a wide age group, including adults and children.
effective_dosage: Not specified for the medical device foam; pimecrolimus cream 1% was used as a comparator.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the characteristics and treatment options for IFAP syndrome, including the use of emollients for managing follicular hyperkeratosis.
results_summary: The study noted that follicular hyperkeratosis in IFAP syndrome can be treated with topical keratolytics, emollients, and urea preparations, though no specific efficacy data for emollients alone were provided.
population_specificity: Patients with IFAP syndrome, a rare X-linked genetic disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of emollients as a pharmacological agent for managing atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: The abstract highlights emollients as one of the pharmacological agents showing great efficacy in treating AD, alongside topical corticosteroids and calcineurin inhibitors. No specific adverse effects or limitations of emollients were mentioned.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of a new emollient cream (containing glycerol, vaseline, and liquid paraffin) compared to a vaseline ointment in improving skin hydration and clinical parameters in patients with severe dry skin undergoing narrow band UVB phototherapy for psoriasis vulgaris.
results_summary: The cream-treated group showed greater improvement in clinical parameters (erythema, desquamation, lichenification) and self-reported responses compared to the vaseline-treated group. Skin hydration improved in the cream group after one week, and the product was well tolerated.
population_specificity: 54 patients (age 18-63) with severe dry skin and moderate psoriasis vulgaris undergoing narrow band UVB phototherapy.
effective_dosage: Twice daily application of either the new cream or vaseline ointment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in the stepped approach to therapy for atopic dermatitis (AD), particularly in comparison to topical corticosteroids and calcineurin inhibitors.
results_summary: Emollients are recommended as the first step in AD therapy, with additional medications added as needed. The abstract highlights the safety and efficacy challenges of traditional topical corticosteroids in children and infants, while noting improved therapeutic indices for fourth-generation corticosteroids like methylprednisolone aceponate.
population_specificity: Infants and children with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of emollients, betamethasone, and tacrolimus on stratum corneum lipids and skin barrier parameters in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: Emollients showed no significant effect on the ceramide/cholesterol ratio or ceramide subgroups compared to betamethasone and tacrolimus. Pretreatment with emollients did not reduce the inflammatory response to sodium lauryl sulphate as effectively as betamethasone or tacrolimus.
population_specificity: 19 healthy volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of emollients in feminine hygiene products through clinical testing.
results_summary: Clinical studies confirmed the safety and efficacy of emollient-containing feminine hygiene products, demonstrating dermatological benefits in the genital area. Testing was conducted on various body sites, including the genital area, with reliable results.
population_specificity: Feminine hygiene product users (specific demographic details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of subclassifying atopic dermatitis (AD) patients based on pathophysiologic modifications to enable individualized treatment approaches, including emollients.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that emollients are part of baseline therapy for AD, but the focus is on the need for subclassification to target specific modified pathways for more effective treatment. It highlights the potential of combining general disease features with individual trigger factors for better therapeutic outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of methylprednisolone aceponate (MPA), a fourth-generation topical corticosteroid, in managing atopic dermatitis (AD), focusing on its chemical structure, pharmacokinetics, efficacy, safety, and dosing considerations.
results_summary: MPA demonstrated an optimized efficacy/safety profile with minimal local or systemic adverse effects and allowed for once-daily dosing, improving patient compliance. It was effective in managing moderate-to-severe AD symptoms when emollients alone were insufficient.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis (AD).
effective_dosage: Once-daily dosing (specific amount not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to outline the current and potential future treatments for atopic dermatitis, including emollients, and highlight areas for improvement.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that emollients are part of the standard therapy for atopic dermatitis but emphasizes the need for further research to enhance existing treatments and explore new therapeutic options.
population_specificity: Not specified (general atopic dermatitis patients implied).

study_goal: The study aimed to compare the effectiveness of gabapentin, cetirizine, and their combination in relieving post-burn itch, but did not evaluate emollients.
results_summary: The study did not assess emollients, focusing instead on gabapentin and cetirizine.
population_specificity: Post-burn patients with pruritus (20 patients per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a new emollient cream containing milk proteins and Glycyrrhiza glabra extracts in patients with palmar and/or plantar psoriasis treated with topical corticotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that patients treated with corticotherapy combined with the emollient showed significantly greater improvement in desquamation, affected surface area, and subjective symptoms compared to those treated with corticotherapy alone. All patients achieved a statistically significant reduction in clinical signs by week 4.
population_specificity: 40 patients with palmar and/or plantar psoriasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop consensus guidelines for psoriasis treatment, including the role of emollients as a steroid-sparing topical therapy.
results_summary: The abstract highlights emollients as one of several steroid-sparing topical therapies for psoriasis, particularly in mild to moderate cases, but does not provide specific efficacy data for emollients alone.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to moderate psoriasis (80% of psoriasis cases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in conventional therapy for atopic dermatitis, alongside antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory treatments.
results_summary: Emollients remain a cornerstone of therapy for atopic dermatitis, with recent advances including nonsteroidal therapy for barrier repair and proactive use of topical corticosteroids and calcineurin inhibitors. The study highlights the immunobiologic rationale for minimal anti-inflammatory treatment of residual disease.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a skin-care program, including emollients, combined with individual counseling and classification of hand eczema, compared to no intervention in reducing disease severity and improving quality of life among healthcare workers.
results_summary: The study assessed the impact of emollients as part of a broader intervention, but specific results regarding emollients alone were not detailed in the abstract. The primary outcome was observer-blinded assessment of disease severity, with secondary outcomes including unblinded severity assessments, eruption frequency, knowledge of skin protection, behavior, and quality of life.
population_specificity: Healthcare workers with hand eczema in three Danish hospitals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients among topical treatments for managing mild psoriasis in children.
results_summary: Emollients were noted as an effective topical treatment for mild psoriasis in children, alongside other agents like coal tar and corticosteroids, though specific efficacy data were not detailed. The abstract suggests emollients are part of a broader therapeutic approach tailored to age and affected sites.
population_specificity: Children with mild psoriasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of emollients in pediatric atopic dermatitis treatment, particularly in reducing severity scores and the need for topical corticosteroids.
results_summary: Emollients significantly reduced severity scores when combined with desonide 0.05% compared to desonide alone (80% vs 70%; p < 0.01) and are recommended for all pediatric patients with atopic dermatitis.
population_specificity: Children under 18 years of age with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy and role of topical therapies, including emollients, in the management of psoriasis.
results_summary: The study found that emollients, among other topical therapies, are safe and effective for managing psoriasis, particularly when used appropriately. The review highlights the importance of awareness of available products for optimal treatment selection.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriasis under the care of family physicians or dermatologists.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing chronic actinic dermatitis (CAD), particularly in elderly populations.
results_summary: The study suggests that emollients, alongside sunlight avoidance, sunscreens, and topical corticosteroids, are part of the management strategy for CAD. No specific efficacy data for emollients alone were provided.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with chronic actinic dermatitis (CAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the natural history of uremic pruritus (UP) and evaluate the effectiveness of treatments, including emollients, in managing itching and improving quality of life.
results_summary: Two-thirds of patients used medications like emollients without satisfactory relief of itching. The study found significant associations between itching intensity and reduced quality of life, but emollients did not provide adequate symptom control.
population_specificity: 103 patients with uremic pruritus on chronic hemodialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the management of atopic eczema in children, focusing on the role of emollients and other treatments, and identify causes of treatment failure.
results_summary: The study found that emollients, combined with anti-inflammatory agents and patient education, are effective in managing atopic eczema in children, but treatment failure may occur due to non-compliance or persistent triggers. Systemic immunosuppression should only be considered after other measures fail.
population_specificity: Children with atopic eczema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review treatment options, including emollients, for mild-to-moderate psoriasis and evaluate their efficacy and safety.
results_summary: Emollients were mentioned as a treatment option for very mild psoriasis, but the abstract primarily focuses on the superior efficacy of vitamin D analogues and corticosteroids, particularly in combination. No specific results for emollients were detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with mild-to-moderate psoriasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of lotion transfer from feminine protection pads to the skin using a modified BTK test model and compare it with clinical in-use studies.
results_summary: Lotion transfer was directly related to the amount of lotion applied, with pads containing AGM cores transferring lotion more effectively than cellulose cores. Clinical in-use results aligned directionally with BTK findings but lacked statistical significance.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely general consumers of feminine protection products).
effective_dosage: Not specified (varied amounts of lotion applied to pads).
study_duration: 3 hours per pad application (up to 6 hours for some tests).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical practice for treating atopic dermatitis (AD), including the role of emollients in maintaining skin barrier function.
results_summary: Emollients have long been used to maintain skin barrier function in AD patients. The study highlights their role alongside other treatments like topical corticosteroids and calcineurin inhibitors, but does not provide specific efficacy data for emollients alone.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis, including children and adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of emollients as a topical treatment for seborrhoeic dermatitis of the scalp, face, and body in adults.
results_summary: The study included emollients among several interventions for seborrhoeic dermatitis but did not provide specific details on their effectiveness compared to other treatments. The abstract suggests emollients were considered but does not highlight distinct outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with seborrhoeic dermatitis of the scalp, face, and body.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review innovations in formulations and techniques for drug-delivery of topical and injectable local anesthetics, including the role of emollients.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that emollients are part of topical delivery systems for local anesthetics, which aim to reduce concentration, enhance permeability, prolong effects, and decrease toxicity. However, specific results on emollients alone are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of formulations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of prednisolone and ciclosporin for severe eczema, with emollients used as part of concomitant treatment.
results_summary: The study did not focus on emollients' efficacy or safety but included them as part of standard care alongside topical steroids and antihistamines. No specific outcomes related to emollients were reported.
population_specificity: Adults with severe eczema (objective SCORAD ≥ 40 and Dermatology Life Quality Index ≥ 10).
study_duration: 6 weeks (active treatment phase) with additional 12-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current understanding of how emollients and other interventions support skin barrier function and mitigate atopic dermatitis and related allergic disorders.
results_summary: The study found that emollients, alongside other therapies like topical corticosteroids and probiotics, help manage atopic dermatitis by improving skin barrier function and reducing inflammation. Early use of emollients may also prevent the development of food allergies and asthma in at-risk infants.
population_specificity: Individuals with atopic dermatitis, particularly infants at risk for allergic disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an overview of EAET's theoretical background, core treatment principles, and empirical evidence from RCTs in alleviating somatic symptoms in people with persistent physical symptoms (PPS).
results_summary: EAET demonstrated efficacy in reducing somatic symptoms, with results superior to cognitive-behavioral therapy, particularly for chronic pain conditions like fibromyalgia and musculoskeletal pain. Further studies are needed to evaluate long-term efficacy and identify patient characteristics linked to positive outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with persistent physical symptoms (PPS), including chronic (primary) pain conditions such as fibromyalgia and musculoskeletal pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility of delivering Emotional Awareness and Expression Therapy (EAET) to individuals with chronic pain following traumatic orthopaedic injuries requiring surgery.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, with data collection expected by 2026; no results on efficacy or outcomes are yet reported.
population_specificity: Individuals who sustained traumatic orthopaedic injuries requiring surgery and reported chronic pain 6 months after hospital discharge.
effective_dosage: Eight sessions of individually administered EAET.
study_duration: Eight sessions (duration per session not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the treatment effects of Internet-delivered Emotional Awareness and Expression Therapy (I-EAET) for somatic symptom disorder were maintained 12 months after treatment.
results_summary: The study found that the beneficial effects of I-EAET on somatic symptoms and pain intensity observed at post-treatment were maintained at the 12-month follow-up, with medium effects on somatic symptoms and small, non-significant effects for pain intensity. Response rates at 12-month follow-up were 25% for somatic symptoms and 12% for pain intensity.
population_specificity: Individuals with somatic symptom disorder (28 out of 37 original participants provided follow-up data).
study_duration: 12-month follow-up after treatment (intervention duration not specified in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of transitioning Emotional Awareness and Expression Therapy (EAET) to a telehealth format during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The study found that EAET could successfully facilitate powerful emotional expressions via video telehealth, supporting its potential efficacy in psychodynamically-informed treatments, despite initial implementation barriers.
population_specificity: Veterans with chronic pain at VA Greater Los Angeles Healthcare System.
